text:
STEVE CARSON: Hello, everyone. And thank you for joining us for
today's discussion, Advancing the OpenCourseWare Movement--

Challenges and Achievements. My name is Steve Carson, I'm
External Relations Director for MIT OpenCourseWare.

And I'm joined
today by two leaders of the OpenCourseWare movement,
Professor Shigeru Miyagawa, who

was one of the original
committee members who first proposed
MIT OpenCourseWare and is currently the Chair of
the MIT OpenCourseWare Faculty

Advisory Committee. He is also the Chair of
MIT's Foreign Languages and Literatures Department.

I'm also joined by
Mary Lou Forward, who is the Executive Director of
the OpenCourseWare Consortium

and previously managed
student programs in Africa for SIT International. So, thank you both
for joining us today.

Let me take a few minutes to set
the stage for the discussion. On April 4th, 2011,
we're going to celebrate

the 10th anniversary of
MIT OpenCourseWare, which was announced on the front
page of The New York Times

on that date in 2001. The article announced MIT's
plans to publish the core

academic materials-- the
syllabi, lecture notes, quizzes, and exams-- from all of MIT'S courses.

And the impact of this
simple yet far-reaching idea is becoming more widely
recognized over time.

But let me just give you a
few highlights of what we've achieved in the past 10 years.

To date, we have 2,000
courses of material on the MIT OpenCourseWare site. And these materials have been
visited more than 100 million

times by people from
virtually every country and region on the planet.

Over 800 translations
of OCW materials have been made, in a range of
different languages including

Chinese, Spanish, Portuguese,
Thai, and Persian. More than 250 copies
of the site have

been distributed by
request to universities in bandwidth-constrained
regions, primarily in sub-Saharan Africa.

And more than 200
universities worldwide have joined MIT in openly
sharing educational content

on the web using the
OpenCourseWare model. Together, these universities
now share materials from more than 13,000 courses
taught in their classrooms.

In addition to
that, OpenCourseWare and the open educational
resources movement have now become part
of the discussion

at the US Department
of Education as they plan for
transformation in education here in the United
States and have

been become part
of the conversation at Ministries of Education
around the world.

So although it was a
simple idea that came out of a small faculty
committee, it's

had far-reaching impact to date. And we're looking
forward to the next 10 years of OpenCourseWare.

So first what I'd like to do
is ask you, Professor Miyagawa, to take us back to
2001, to that committee,

and talk a little bit
about the atmosphere around online learning-- what it was like at the time.

What influenced the
committee's thinking in terms of making the
proposal that they made? SHIGERU MIYAGAWA: OK. Thank you, Steve.

So I'm Shigeru Miyagawa. I chair the MIT OpenCourseWare
Faculty Advisory Committee.

And I also had a fortunate role
of being on the committee that

proposed OpenCourseWare. Let me begin, though, by
thanking you for your interest

and support in MIT
OpenCourseWare. MIT OpenCourseWare is
an MIT community effort.

We all pitch in. We have huge participation from
the faculty and other teaching

staff and beyond. And with your
interest and support, you are very much
part of the community.

And so on behalf of the
faculty, I thank you. So the story of
OpenCourseWare begins

in year 2000, when the
President of MIT, Charles Vest,

called together a
committee to think about what MIT can do
in this new, emerging

field of e-learning. We were reading about e-learning
almost on a daily basis.
This was 10 years ago--

it was still the dot-com era. And we were reading
in the newspaper

of another successful
IPO, just in that. And e-learning was very
much in that space.

MIT was not engaged
in e-learning. And the President
was concerned that we

should be in that space. And to be in that space as
a leader, as MIT should be.

And so what the committee did-- none of us were
experts in e-learning.

And so what we had to do was
to learn about e-learning. And so one of the
first things we did

was to do a study of
e-learning ventures that were going on
around the country.

And that was a very
big learning process. And we enjoyed it-- we
still have that report.

It was part of the
report that we finally gave to President Vest. And we were told
at the time that it

was the thickest report ever
turned in by an MIT committee. And so we did our due diligence
to come to that decision.

As part of the process
in making the decision,

we really did study the
landscape of e-learning to see what it is that MIT could
do that could, in our own way,

take leadership in the space. STEVE CARSON: Great. So, what forces
compelled the committee

to decide against doing a
traditional distance learning program? Certainly that was one of the
things that you had considered.

SHIGERU MIYAGAWA: In fact,
going in, because of the dot-com atmosphere, the assumption was
that we would create some kind
of a for-profit organization-- an mit.com, if you will.

And the studies that we engaged
in, we did with the assumption

that we will try to come up
with a business model that would make it feasible and
viable and credible for MIT

to take some leadership position
in this for-profit landscape.

But as we looked into the
matter, a couple of things became apparent, which
ultimately led us

to the decision to
do OpenCourseWare. One was that, in looking at
all of these organizations that

were engaged in for-profit
ventures and e-learning,

it was apparent to us that
this is a very tough area to do business in--

to take teaching
materials and sell it. It's something that
seemed, at first, to be

a pretty obvious thing to do. But as we looked at the
cost versus the revenue,

it was not so apparent that
it would be a wonderful model.

And so that was a
big question mark. The second thing that we did was
to really think for ourselves,

as faculty members, should
we, as faculty members, create teaching materials--

which are for our students-- which will also be
sold out in the market?

And we started to
feel uncomfortable with that concept-- the idea that we would take
our teaching materials,

which we tied to
education, and then somehow link it to some
kind of monetary value.

And ultimately,
we decided, given these two issues, that MIT--

yes, should be in the space. And we should take leadership. But we should
create a new model--

not a for-profit, dot-com model. But to really take advantage
of this wide, open space

that the internet was
making available to us. And so the idea that we came up
with was to take what we have

and simply give it away. Give it away for free, openly,
to anyone who wants to use it.

STEVE CARSON: Great. So tell me a little bit about
who the committee originally believed was going to benefit
from making these materials

widely available. And how has that changed? Or how has the usage of the
site surprised you over time?

SHIGERU MIYAGAWA: Well,
there's been so many surprises since we made a decision.

We have been stunned
and so pleased at the huge numbers of
people who are using OCW.

Something like a million people
come and view MIT OCW material on a monthly basis.

That's just beyond
our wildest dreams. When we first made this
decision to offer our courseware

for free and openly, we had
hoped that you would benefit-- some people out
there who might be

interested in learning something
that they were interested in.

And possibly those in
third-world countries who didn't have access to
education and to teaching

materials, that
they could benefit. And that's all happening.

And it's happening
in huge numbers. We show this map of the
world and the access rate

from each part and we see
that people coming literally from all over the world.

And actually, Mary
Lou is the person who is in charge of the
global OCW consortium.

And so it's not
just that people are coming to see MIT
OpenCourseWare, but that other
schools are launching

their own OpenCourseWare. And so that was our hope
and that expectation

is certainly being
met and met beyond our wildest expectations.

STEVE CARSON: I know from
reading some of the documents from the early
days of the program that the committee, early
on, and the people who

were developing the first
stages of the program were very interested in
seeing other schools adopt

this model as well. They felt that there
would be benefit from MIT in sharing
its materials, but that this idea
of OpenCourseWare

wouldn't truly be
transformative for education unless other schools
around the world were sharing their materials.

And MIT had the opportunity
to learn from them as well. So you were also very involved
in some of the early efforts

to bring other schools on board
with sharing their content? Would you share a little
bit about those activities

in that piece of the OCW story? SHIGERU MIYAGAWA: Sure. Now, in terms of what
the committee proposed

to the president, we actually
proposed a couple of things. The one that
everyone knows about is the idea of
launching OCW at MIT.

But as Steve said,
we also believed that if this is
successful and that MIT

is able to build this OCW
model, that it would not be enough for just MIT to do that.

Because we were truly
introducing a new model into the internet space of a
major educational institution,

offering its teaching
materials for free and openly. And we felt very strongly
that in order for this model

to succeed and to have
the kind of impact that we felt they
could have, that we

had to reach out to other
institutions around the world and encourage them to
adopt the same model.

We started building MIT
OpenCourseWare in 2001.

In 2005, we invited a number of
people from other institutions,

both in the US and
also in Europe and Asia to MIT to begin the
process of creating

a global OpenCourseWare
presence.

That was in 2005. There were maybe 12 or
15 schools at that time.

And as Mary Lou
can tell you later, we are now well above
200 institutions,

many of them representing
some of the top schools in their respective countries.

STEVE CARSON: Mary
Lou, why don't you pick up the story from there
and tell us a little bit more about adoption worldwide of
the OpenCourseWare concept?

Where schools have emerged
sharing their content and also how the Consortium
itself developed.

MARY LOU FORWARD: From
that meeting in 2005 where, as Shigeru
mentioned, there were about 12 universities,
the interest in OCW

increased dramatically. And over the next few
years, the Consortium really began to take off,
to the point where

the decision was made
to form the Consortium as a separate entity. So that happened
about two years ago

and we've seen membership
growing since then in regions all over the world, actually. Our current membership is around
240 institutions worldwide.

And that is equally divided
between South America, Europe, Asia, and North America.

And we're beginning
to see this year a lot more increased interest from
Africa, which is fabulous.

And we're happy to
see participation from all parts of the world. At the moment, there are
just over 13,000 courses

that are being produced. And if you think of MIT's
portion of that at 2,000, you can see that schools have
really embraced this concept

and contributed greatly
to the worldwide body of OpenCourseWare. STEVE CARSON: Great.

And talk about the goals of
the OpenCourseWare Consortium. Why does the consortium exist? What is it set up to do?

MARY LOU FORWARD: The
Consortium's mission is to empower formal
and informal learning through the sharing of
high-quality open educational

materials. And this is part
of a larger vision to ensure equal access to
high-quality post-secondary

education for people around the
world who may not necessarily have that access right now.

So the Consortium
works differently than other organizations
in this space by making sure that
the courses are put up

with pedagogical
information so it's an entire package of materials
that allows students,

self-learners, and
faculty members to see not just
what the content is, but how it's constructed
to facilitate learning.

STEVE CARSON: Great. Talk a little bit about
why a school would want to start an OpenCourseWare.

Obviously, we've seen tremendous
adoption of the concept and there's a lot
of interest in it.

aspect of helping people? MARY LOU FORWARD:
We've seen certainly that there have been a
lot of benefits, I think,

that probably weren't originally
envisioned by the faculty committee at MIT. For one thing, it
actually raises

the profile of institutions. And where it may feel a bit
contrary to the idea of giving

something away,
it actually helps students see what they would get
by coming to the institution. So that level of
transparency has

been really important
for prospective students to decide where to go to school. It's also helped students
in many institutions

around the world support
their own learning. So if a student is perhaps
struggling with a concept,

they can see how it's presented
at another institution. And that actually benefits
the home institution,

by having students
that understand things better and have it be stronger. So to participate in this
global movement is critical.

It's also helping
the institution be known for its specialties. So we have some
institutions-- for example,

The University of Technology
in Delft, in the Netherlands, that has put up their water
management curriculum.

And if you are on
a search engine-- just a general search for
water management information--

their courses come up. And they are getting
well-known around the world and being contacted by other
institutions and by agencies

to help them figure out how
to create their own water management materials,
or help with consulting. So there have been
all kinds of really

interesting and unexpected
effects of OpenCourseWare. STEVE CARSON: Great. So it's certainly an
extraordinary story,

the amount of interest that
this idea has generated

and the amount of
activity this idea has generated in
the past 10 years. And I'll come back
to Professor Miyagawa

in a minute with a
similar question about MIT OpenCourseWare. But more broadly, what do you
see on the horizon, Mary Lou,

for the OpenCourseWare movement? What's coming in
the next 10 years? MARY LOU FORWARD: It's actually
a really exciting time.

You mentioned earlier that
the concept has grown. It's grown to the point where
it's actually getting attention

at the governmental level. So we're seeing around the world
different governments beginning to embrace the idea
of open education.

And OpenCourseWare is
synonymous with open education. So when people are talking
about open educational resources

and OpenCourseWare, they tend
to use those interchangeably, which is a testament to
how powerful this idea is

and how wide the
adoption has become. For example, in Brazil they
held a congressional hearing not

very long ago-- back in August-- about how open
educational resources could support Brazilian
goals in their higher

education and secondary
educational systems. We're seeing in
Korea, for example,

that the program for
excellence that's given out to institutions
of higher education

to improve their
teaching and learning has an OpenCourseWare
requirement so that any recipient
of this grant

must take the materials
they develop and put it back into the OpenCourseWare space. We're also seeing governments
such as the state of Washington

in the US and New Zealand
adopting openness policies, so that any institution that
receives government funding

makes their materials
openly available. And this includes OpenCourseWare
and open education. So we're seeing, I think,
in the next five years,

more of this happening. And as this happens, more
people will know about it and the real potential
of OpenCourseWare

to help support improvements
in teaching and learning is going to be realized. STEVE CARSON: Great, thank you.

So I think it's
apparent, at least to me, that MIT OpenCourseWare as a
project now is, in some sense,

a victim of its own success. Where before we had an open
field to be the innovator,

we are now surrounded
by universities around the world who are
sharing their content in new and innovative ways.

Governments are
getting into the act. We've got foundations basing
some of their programs

around open educational
resources and OpenCourseWare. And that presents a challenge
for MIT OpenCourseWare

and remaining an
innovative leader in the open education space. And so Professor
Miyagawa, I was hoping

you could tell us a little
bit about future directions you see for the MIT
OpenCourseWare project.

SHIGERU MIYAGAWA: Well, I'm
very optimistic about the future of MIT OpenCourseWare.

Next year, 2011, we're going to
celebrate our 10th anniversary of the start of MIT
OpenCourseWare, which,

as Steve mentioned earlier,
was announced in year 2001. And one of the things that
has been a huge surprise--

and a very pleasant surprise-- is the fact that so
many MIT faculty have

participated in OpenCourseWare. This was not something that we
were certain of, because it was

strictly on voluntary
basis-- and still is-- that you put your
material on OpenCourseWare

as an MIT faculty. And it took a while for
the momentum to build.

But once the momentum
built, within a few years into building of
OpenCourseWare, we now

have 80% of MIT faculty
members who are participating

in OpenCourseWare. That's just remarkable. And it really is an
indication, I think,

of this MIT community
and its commitment

to helping the world. And its commitment to
values of openness.

And it really has caught on. And I still remember a
junior faculty member here

at MIT telling me, shortly after
OpenCourseWare was announced, that the day that MIT
announced OpenCourseWare

was the proudest day
of his career at MIT. And I remember that.

And so that kind of
commitment is there. It's getting stronger.

And so as we look to
the next 10 years, we can look for
many exciting things

to come out of MIT
OpenCourseWare. One thing that we are
starting to see now which is very
interesting and exciting

is that we now know that
half of the people who are looking at
MIT OpenCourseWare

are self-learners. Those are people who are
interested in some topic,

whatever the topic
may be, and they find something on
MIT OpenCourseWare

and they drill down into it. Now, MIT OpenCourseWare is
a set of teaching materials

that faculty members
have provided. Those teaching materials
are designed for students.

They're not designed for the
self-learners out in the world. Sometimes, the
course is complete

and a self-learner who can come
in and study physics or math.

But what we're doing now
with some of the courses is to enhance the
content so that we

can enhance the experience
of these self-learners. And so now we're going a little
bit beyond MIT OpenCourseWare

as it was originally envisioned,
as MIT OpenCourseWare, and adding material
for the people who

are out there in the world
accessing this content to study.

STEVE CARSON: Great. Thank you. So I think what we'll do now
is turn our attention to some of the questions
that we've received from some of our viewers in
the lead-up to this webcast.

And Mary Lou, I'm going to ask
you to respond to this first question, which comes
from [? Krishnamurthy ?] [? Ramapria, ?] who would
like to know if there are any

business companies out there
that provide courses in the OCW manner and are free of cost?

And perhaps if any of them
have certification options associated with them.

MARY LOU FORWARD:
We're seeing, I would say, a greater
interest from business in OpenCourseWare. I think originally businesses
were looking at OpenCourseWare

as a way for them to perhaps
train their employees in areas that they may not have received
education in previously.

For example, we've been
talking with the Small Business Administration and they're
very interested in using OpenCourseWare as a way to
help educate the small business

community in the United
States about business and to offer
OpenCourseWare and open

a courseware channel on the
Small Business Administration site. So we are, I think,
seeing businesses

become more interested in that. At the moment, I don't
know of any businesses that have taken their own
internal training materials

and turned them
into OpenCourseWare. We hope that that's
going to happen, because that would, again, be a
good contribution, particularly

to job skills training
and workforce preparation. STEVE CARSON: Great. And of course, the
OpenCourseWare Consortium

has, as part of its
membership, in addition to the institutions
of higher education,

other types of organizations. Maybe you should mention
those really quickly. MARY LOU FORWARD: Yes,
we have businesses

that are creating all kinds of
things around OpenCourseWare. So we have institutions
or organizations

that are creating services
to help identify and package OpenCourseWare for
other institutions,

as a value-added service. We also have a
number of businesses that support OpenCourseWare
through the membership

in the Consortium-- software
companies, for example. We have a very interesting
organization in Texas--

the city of Manor, Texas. The assistant city manager
has found OpenCourseWare

to be very interesting
and has issued a challenge to his citizens to come
up with the OpenCourseWare

that they would like to see
as a public education program. And he will reward citizens
for generating ideas

with gift certificates and
things from local businesses. So I think we're going to see
a municipal government creating

OpenCourseWare within
the next few months. They have a few planned already. One is on civil society.

STEVE CARSON: Fantastic. We have a question coming in
from a viewer, Derek Lewis, who's asking how much has
been invested in MIT's

OpenCourseWare site to date? And how much does it cost to
produce a full video course? And I can give the
basic numbers--

but perhaps, Professor
Miyagawa, you'd like to comment afterward. MIT OpenCourseWare-- to publish
the original 1,800 courses

required an investment
of around $30 million. $25 million of that came
from the Hewlett and Mellon

Foundations and
$5 million of that came directly from
MIT's core budget. The program on an ongoing basis
costs us about $3.3 million

to operate, about half
of which continues to be paid by MIT directly. And the other half we're
paying for currently

with reserve funds. And we are obviously
building a donation program and a corporate
sponsorship program that

will help sustain
us in the long haul, once those grant
reserves are expended. So that's the basics
of our cost structure.

The reason why it costs
about $3.3 million a year for us to operate the program
is because the most valuable

resource we have here at MIT
really is our faculty time. And in order for this
program to be successful,

we need to ensure that
sharing materials openly does not require an inordinate
amount of faculty time.

Because they do provide
their materials voluntarily-- they provide their time
voluntarily to the program.

So we have a staff
of about 20 people here at MIT OpenCourseWare that
help to collect format, clear

copyright on the
materials, and make sure they appear on the web in
the format that you see them.

And in particular, video courses
are more expensive for us.

It typically takes us
about $10,000 a course, if you divide it all out. A video course will cost between
$25,000 to $35,000 in total.

So that's the basic
cost structure. Perhaps you'd like to comment
a little bit about how

the program is financed. SHIGERU MIYAGAWA: So, Steve
mentioned that about half of the CW operation
is being paid by MIT.

Now originally, this was
really not in the plan. And it's important to give the
reason why MIT is doing that.

As I mentioned
earlier, we thought that the biggest beneficiary
will be people out there

using MIT's teaching materials. But as MIT's OCW became
bigger and bigger,

it became quite apparent
to us that there are many benefits to MIT.

I've already mentioned
that 80% of the faculty participate in OCW. As a result of participation,
the teaching materials

have improved because they
know that OCW is being viewed by a million people.

So naturally, the
material that they produce will have that audience
in mind as well.

So it's been a big
benefit to our students.

MIT students view
OCW in huge numbers-- something like 90%
of the MIT students

use OCW for a
variety of reasons. What courses to
take next, courses

that they are
taking now but they need some supplementary material
from the previous offering.

Many creative reasons. So there are many
benefits to MIT,

which has been one of the
biggest surprises for me. And so MIT is committed to
supporting OCW at the level

that it's supporting now,
but at the same time, it is important that the
OCW is a huge benefit

to the rest of the world. And for that, we
need to continue to do the campaigns
to support OCW.

STEVE CARSON: Great. And one of the things
I should also note is that MIT is a much larger
scale OpenCourseWare than many

of the other
OpenCourseWares out there, which are operating on
much more modest funding, with smaller staff sizes
and lower cost structures.

So Mary Lou, maybe you
could talk a little bit about the size of some of the
other OpenCourseWares that are out there?

The kind of staffing
models they've been using. MARY LOU FORWARD:
The projects that are being produced now run
anything from a single staff

member to probably five or six
as the next largest after MIT's

efforts. And the number of courses
can range from anything from a couple up
to a few hundred.

We're seeing that as
institutions adopt this and as they see the
internal benefits that

were referenced
just a minute ago, they tend to invest more in it. And they invest by
reallocating their resources,

not necessarily adding
additional resources to the university's budget.

So as students become more
savvy in using OpenCourseWare and selecting their
courses, universities

are beginning to
be able to divert some of their advising funds,
for example, into efforts like OpenCourseWare.

And also they don't
necessarily have to produce as much PR output
for things like the Distance

Education program as their
profile is raised through being seen in OpenCourseWare.

We're also seeing a
number of institutions that are adopting a student
model, where they're

having work study funds actually
fund students to come in, learn about copyright, learn how to
copyright-clear materials--

which is very important-- and
produce the OpenCourseWare on a lower budgetary scale.

I think overall,
though, it ultimately relies still on a lot of
volunteer efforts of faculty.

Faculty are very key in
producing their materials, getting them ready
for OpenCourseWare. And in some schools,
the faculty actually

get their materials
up to a certain level before turning it over
for final production. So the models are
varying greatly.

And it also depends on the kinds
of courses they're producing. You're seeing many more video
courses that are coming out.

There seems to be a
great interest in that with this audience as well. So you're seeing
institutions that

are bringing in their
learning technology labs right into the classroom to
do those videos up front.

And that makes loading
them up into OpenCourseWare a whole lot easier. STEVE CARSON: Great. And I should say, to
scale MIT OpenCourseWare

against the programs you were
talking about-- we publish about 200 courses worth
of material each year

and probably three
to five video courses as a part of that publication.

And so you can see we're
an order of magnitude larger than many of the other
OpenCourseWares out there.

And we are the only
one that represents the entire curriculum
of a university.

We have all 33 of the
academic departments here at MIT represented, both
undergraduate and graduate.

So we have another
question from a viewer that was submitted
before the video started,

from Zachary Wiesner. And he was asking
if we could talk about how people, both
individuals and groups, make use of the
course materials.

And if we have any
recommendations for how best to do so. So I can give the basics
of who uses OpenCourseWare

and how our audience breaks
down between about 9% educators, 42% students
at other universities,

and 43% of these
independent learners that Professor Miyagawa
was speaking about.

Again, we have about a
million unique individuals who come to the site each
month-- about a million and a half visits.

And we've been able to
document, through surveys, a wide range of activities
that the site supports.

I think when most people
think of OpenCourseWare, the first thing that comes
to mind is distance learning. But MIT OpenCourseWare really
isn't a distance learning site.

It's a reference and a resource
for undertaking a range of educational activities. All of the materials
are licensed openly,

which allows our users to
download the materials, modify the materials,
and reformat the materials for
their own needs--

and redistribute them
to other audiences. And so that allows
educators to do things like take the lecture
notes out of a class,

reformat them, and use them
in their own classroom. It allows them to look at
our curricular structures--

because we cover all of
the academic departments, undergraduate and graduate. For instance, we've talked
to an architecture department

head in Indonesia
who was reformulating how his school
teaches architecture. And he wasn't adopting
MIT'S approach directly,

but he was using the
site as a reference to look at how MIT
thinks about teaching a subject like architecture. What do we teach first?

What do we teach second? What do we teach third? Faculty members
also use the site around the world as a
resource for improving

their own knowledge. It is some of the
best information in the field for many
of the departments

that we have here at MIT. Especially in
resource-poor environments, it allows educators to upgrade
their own personal knowledge

and expand their own learning. Among students,
we find that they use the material to supplement
the materials they get

from their own faculty members. So if they're struggling
with a concept, they need a different
explanation,

they can come to our
site, watch the video, read the relevant
lecture notes, and have a second take at the material.

Very often, they use the site to
study beyond their own courses that they're taking so that they
can learn about other topics.

They won't have a chance to
study while they're undertaking their formal education.

And finally, the site turns
out to be very useful, both within MIT and outside
of MIT, as an advising

and educational planning tool. It allows students to do
things like figure out, do they really want
to be in a field

like mechanical engineering? What do mechanical
engineers do when they get to the graduate level? What kinds of topics
do they study?

It also allows them to
make more granular choices. What course do I
want to take next?

What can I expect if I'm
taking linear algebra? What do the materials look
like for a course like that?

And it also--
especially here at MIT, we've noticed it provides
the opportunity for students to flash back and flash
forward through the material.

So if they're an
intro math class and they want to know where this
concept is going to be applied, they can go to the
junior aeronautics class

where it's actually used. Or if they're in that
junior aeronautics class and they've forgotten the
formula they were supposed

to know, they can go back to the
math class and learn it again. So we've certainly seen that. And I think the widest
open field that we've seen

is this field of
independent learners who use the site in a whole
range of different ways.

About half of the
ways we've documented from independent
learners are ways that are basically for personal
use-- for the joy of learning,

for homeschooling
their children, for doing personal projects.

And then the other half
that we've documented are really professional
uses, where people are either
reviewing the basics

in their professional
field or keeping up with the latest trends in
their field, or, in some cases,

trying to solve particular
technical problems.  That's generally what we know
about how people use the site.

And so for that reason,
it becomes a little bit difficult to give general
recommendations on how

best to use the materials. It's kind of like asking how
best to use the encyclopedia. But I think one thing you
can do is, on our website,

in the About Us section,
there's a section of OCW stories that document different ways
users have accessed materials

and used the materials. And reading those stories
might give you some good ideas. But it really depends
on whether you're

coming at it as an
educator, as a student, or as an independent learner. Does anyone else want
to comment on that?

SHIGERU MIYAGAWA: Just to add
to what Steve just mentioned, one decision that
we made early on,

which has been very
helpful, is that we decided to make the
teaching materials

available with permission of
copyright cleared so that users

of OpenCourseWare know
that when they are looking at and thinking about using
MIT OpenCourseWare material,

they know that it is free
of copyright restriction--

we've cleared it. And so long as they use
it for non-profit purpose,

that users are able to take it,
copy it, distribute it, alter it however the educator or
the learner wants to use.

And I must say that I
travel a fair amount because

of OpenCourseWare. And wherever I go,
people tell me, gee, I'm using the
linguistics lecture

by Professor Richards
for my class. Or I'm using Walter Lewin's
videos for my physics class.

This happens all the time. STEVE CARSON: We
have another question coming in from Giuseppe, which
is asking, as you probably

know, US high school students
are impoverished in their math and science skills. Do we have any initiatives to
try to push OCW or curriculum

with school districts. And so very briefly, the
answer to that is yes. We do have a
section of our site,

if you look on the left-hand
navigation, that's called highlights for high school. And we launched this in 2007.

And while the site does
not provide materials that were created specifically
for high school students, what

it does provide is access to
the content on our site that is applicable-- that's
come out of MIT classrooms

but is nonetheless applicable
to Advanced Placement study of high school
math and science topics.

And so if you go to that
site, what you'll see is a section that's
called Test Prep. And there's Calculus, Biology,
and Physics subsections.

And what they do is
they provide the AP catalog of subjects that are
studied in high school AP

courses. And we had a team
of freshmen and also high school seniors
go through our site

and identify all the
small bits of material that were appropriate to high
school study of these subjects.

And so it provides
a very quick index and a way that educators and
students can dive into our site and find that material that's
appropriate to the high school

level without having to go
through every single document or every single
video on the site.

So for example, if you're
interested in oscillation of pendulums, for
instance, you can find that in the topic list.

You can click on that. It'll take you to the
five-minute video section at the end of Walter Lewin's
15th lecture in his physics

course-- where before, you would have
had to have gone through all 15 of the lectures to
find that one clip that

addresses that subject. So it provides a great index. I know that Professor
Miyagawa and Mary

Lou both speak and attend
meetings around the country where the topic of secondary
education comes up.

So first, Mary Lou,
could you maybe comment on some of
the things you've heard about secondary education
and how OpenCourseWare might

help address the stem issues? MARY LOU FORWARD: Sure. And I think, Steve,
you mentioned earlier

that a lot of
foundations are becoming interested in OpenCourseWare. And this is one of the
areas that they are really

getting interested
in-- and government policymakers as well. How can OpenCourseWare
support not just

success in particular
subject areas, but success in higher education? Improve graduation rates,
improve student populations

who may not otherwise
get higher education. How can it help bridge that
gap and help show students

that they can be successful? And so we're seeing many more
organizations and foundations really interested in pushing
that particular question.

And we do get a lot
of questions about how can OpenCourseWare
support students who are currently in
particularly the higher

grades of secondary education-- 11th and 12th in this country-- to understand their
subject matter better

and prepare them to think
more independently outside of a more structured
high school curriculum.

How can they think
more independently so that when they
go to university and they begin to be
confronted with these concepts

of critical thinking, they're
already versed in that enough that they can continue
their interest in science

and mathematics? Where a lot of
freshmen may otherwise be scared off because of the
way that things are presented,

which is so differently than
in a secondary curriculum. STEVE CARSON: Great, thank you. Professor Miyagawa,
did you want to comment

on any conversations you've
been involved with regarding secondary ed here in the US? SHIGERU MIYAGAWA: Yeah. One thing that I'm involved in--
and this is my own project--

is a history course that I teach
with my colleague, Professor John Dower here at MIT.

And we have created
quite a large site called Visualizing Cultures, which
is about doing history

using visuals. So we have agreements with
a variety of museums--

Boston MFA, Smithsonian,
and so forth-- that have agreed to provide
images under a Creative Commons

license to our site. So we go around and do workshops
for secondary school teachers.

We are close to
about 800 teachers now that we have trained in
using this visualizing culture

site, which is an OCW site. And one thing that all
the teachers tell us

is that the world is
changing very quickly. And yet they have textbooks
which are years old.

And the advantage to using
this kind of material is that, first of all,
it's free, it's open,

and it's very much up to date. And so we have many
schools around the country

using the site. STEVE CARSON: Thank you. We have another
question from Giuseppe. He's asking, are there any
innovative IT solutions

that are on the horizon
to try to keep costs down? And I would say that there are
some marginal technological

improvements that
we're seeing, primarily in capturing video and audio. It's become a lot
cheaper to do that.

We now, at MIT OpenCourseWare,
support really two levels of video capture. One is the standard high-quality
level that we've been capturing

and then another is sort of a
lower quality hand-held camera that we give to students to
record classroom activities

or field trips or
things like that. So we tend to do the
high-quality capture for full video lecture series
and we do the lower quality

capture to get other types
of material onto the site. But I think typically
what you see

is technological improvements
help us to make the site more rich, to better represent
the course materials that

are out there-- or the course activities
that are out there. But the core business
that we undertake

in gathering faculty
and materials, preparing them for our site,
and putting them up on the web

still requires us
to gather materials that are created in a
wide variety of formats

and are at different
levels of preparedness for sharing online.

And very manually, to prep those
for going up on our website. So it is very difficult
for us to reduce

the core cost of that. That is very much
a manual activity. Over time, we expect that
the faculty members will

begin to adopt a more
common set of digital tools and that will allow
us to leverage

their more common,
richer formats. But as long as we're
continuing to work with PowerPoints and
with Word documents

and with PDFs and LaTeX and
all the other different formats that we get the content
in-- and we have

to convert those for our site. We haven't found any
one silver bullet that's going to help us totally
reduce the cost of doing

what we're doing. Mary Lou, maybe you can comment
on some of the other approaches that schools are taking, that
they're finding ways to reduce

costs using technology. MARY LOU FORWARD: They are. I think I'm one of
the things that you mentioned that is
true in other places

as well is the video capture. That students-- in
particular, self-learners-- are very interested in video
lectures or video courses.

And so there are a number of
projects around the world. There's a big one
out at Berkeley

that's an open cast project
that is looking to automatically capture both the speaker
and the materials

that the speaker is
presenting and begin to edit that in almost real time.

So there's someone in
the back of the room that can capture the image,
adjust it, and then it's ready to go live almost
as soon as the class ends.

And by doing this
in collaboration with a number of institutions
and with a number of learning

management systems,
we're actually seeing that the integration
into OpenCourseWare is both more cost-effective
and a lot quicker,

so that it doesn't
take a semester or two after the course
ends to actually get those materials
live on the site.

That's particularly helpful for
students in a current semester. If they miss a lecture or if
they need reminder about what

happened in that course,
they can go back to it as a reference in
the same semester.

STEVE CARSON: Thank you. So I think one of the
things that we're seeing is an interest in multimedia, an
interest in the different ways

that we're able
to represent what goes on in the classroom in
the OpenCourseWare space.

I think one of the
other interesting things is that we're seeing
some materials emerge that have never been seen
in the digital space before.

And Professor Miyagawa, I
think some of the materials that you've been able to collect
for the visualizing culture site that are available
through MIT OpenCourseWare

are some of the most
wonderful materials that we're seeing emerge in the digital
space for the first time

as part of an
OpenCourseWare project. So maybe you could
talk a little bit about some of those
materials and how you've been

able to get access to them. SHIGERU MIYAGAWA:
So having served

on the original committee
that proposed OpenCourseWare, I wanted to see if we could
take advantage of this project

to offer a course that would
be designed taking advantage of OpenCourseWare.

And so I proposed
to Professor Dower that we create this
history project

in the course that looks at
images as historical text

to try to understand history. Not through written
texts, which is the traditional way
of doing history,

but through images
that we can collect. And try to understand
history through those images.

And as I said, in
order to do that, you have to get the images. And so we approached many
important institutions--

Boston MFA, Smithsonian, Peabody
Essex Museum, museums in Japan,

museums in England. And we continued to expand that. And at every museum, we
explain OpenCourseWare

and we explain that what
we need are not just images but we need images
that can be licensed

to us under this OpenCourseWare
Creative Commons, which allows the user of our site to
download, distribute, alter,

as long as it's for
non-profit purpose. And I've just been very pleased
that so many museums have

decided to sign on and
have made images which have been basically
inaccessible to the public

unless you go to the museum-- or even if you go to the museum,
most of the images are stored.

That now these images are
available in tens of thousands on our site.

STEVE CARSON: Great, thank you. We've got a question
coming in from Derek about the popularity
of video courses

and how much more
popular they are than the document-only-based
presentations.

And we do have metrics
on that, Derek. And what we've seen is
that the video courses

do tend to attract a
much larger audience. The top video, of
course, probably

gets about 60,000 or
so visits each month, whereas your typical
course with documents

might receive
about 10,000 or so. But there are a couple
of qualifications that I should provide with that.

One is that we've
intentionally put the video on the most popular courses. So we've looked at the courses
that have the heaviest traffic

and we've gone out
and we've tried to videotape those courses. And you'll notice that most of
the courses that have videotape

on our site are
introductory level courses that would naturally
have large audiences anyways.

And the other thing is that
the most popular courses on the site are not
exclusively video courses

and that there are
a number of courses that get similar traffic to the
video courses that don't have

video associated with
them, but instead they have some other
rich resource that's very attractive to
independent learners.

So that might be a
textbook or lecture notes that are very
detailed or some other kind of a digital resource that
makes it a very attractive site

for independent learners. But the other thing
about the site is that it really
does attract traffic

in a very long tail fashion. There are a core
group of courses that get the most traffic.

And these are the introductory
undergraduate courses, primarily. And then there are a large
group of courses that

get relatively modest traffic. And these are the
graduate courses. But we think that that
long tail traffic is also

an important aspect of what
we do for a couple of reasons. One is because it presents
the full richness of MIT

as an institution-- what we teach, how we go
about teaching things. And that's very useful for
educators around the world

as they're reformulating
their educational programs and using our site
as a reference.

And the other reason is that
while a course that's, say, on sanitation engineering
at the graduate level

may not be useful to a
broad population of people, it may, on the other hand,
be useful to a small group

of people whose work can have a
tremendous impact on the health and well-being of many
people in their region.

And so we like to include not
only just the very popular courses, but also the courses
that are at the higher level

and are a little bit
more esoteric as well.

I don't know if
you want to comment on other strategies from
other schools, Mary Lou, in terms of including materials
that may be less than popular.

yes, there's wide
demand, particularly among self-learners
for video courses.

But I think schools
are approaching that in a number of different ways. While they are trying
to capture the videos

for the courses
themselves, they're also capturing things
like lecture series that they're running
on particular topics.

So for example, the University
of California at Irvine ran a lecture series
on the Supreme Court

and a number of well-known
professors lectured on that. It's now one of the more
popular package of materials

that you can get
on their website-- more popular than some
of their entire courses,

which are also video-lectured. So part of it does depend
on the theme and the topic that you're talking
about, but I also

believe that a lot
of universities are trying to meet
the needs of who they think their audiences are.

So there's a really
interesting project happening with African
Virtual University, which was established
specifically to address

the need of Africans
who could not attend a traditional
brick-and-mortar university.

They came up with a strategy
a couple of years ago to create teacher
training materials,

because in several
African countries, teachers are in very short
supply and very high demand--

particularly
well-trained teachers. And a lot of the distance
education materials that were available for African
Virtual University to use

were coming from Europe
and the United States, where the context is
completely different. So what they decided to
do was to bring together

12 institutions from
10 different countries to create teaching
material specifically for the African context, in
three languages-- so in French,

in English, and in Portuguese. And they did that
with the outcome that it would become
OpenCourseWare

so that this becomes a resource
for the entire continent. And even though these
materials are not video based,

they're very popular
and they stand to actually have huge effect. And they did this for a
particular need that they felt,

rather than popularity. STEVE CARSON: Great, thank you. We have a comment
coming in from Derek.

This really isn't
a question, but he writes, "What you
pioneered is one of the most wonderful
developments in education

and world history." And I just wanted to thank
Derek for the comment

and also to mention that
these kinds of messages, these support
messages that we get

are very important to us
here at MIT OpenCourseWare. And we pass them
along to the faculty

that we work with who are
donating their materials and make sure that they
understand the gratitude that people feel worldwide.

We receive 30 or 40
emails a day from users out there who thank us
or give us suggestions.

Obviously, we have
supporters around the world who help us financially. And this is a vital
part of what we do.

Without that outside
input, we would not be able to continue to maintain
the level of enthusiasm we have

among the faculty and
the level of effort that we're able to put forward
with our staff in capturing the content for the site.

So thank you for that comment. Keep the good comments coming. And we'll continue to pass
them on to the MIT faculty who

really deserve your thanks. So with that, I think
we'd like to wrap up. I'll give each one
of our panelists

an opportunity to share
maybe some closing thoughts. And I want to personally
thank all of you

for joining us on
the webcast today. So first, Mary Lou, do you
have any closing comments? MARY LOU FORWARD: Sure.

I wanted to just echo what
Professor Miyagawa said earlier-- to thank you, as a community,
as a worldwide audience

for these materials and
supporters of OpenCourseWare-- for your support for
attending the webcast today.

But also, moreover, for
your general interest and your enthusiasm in
promoting OpenCourseWare

to the rest of the world. And MIT has something to
be extremely proud of--

that you've started a
movement that has obviously caught on in ways I think that
no one imagined 10 years ago.

Not just with universities,
not just with learners, not just with faculty,
but with governments. People are realizing
the powerful idea

of sharing and rediscovering
that, by opening yourself up, you actually
strengthen yourself.

So MIT once again has become
a pioneer in higher education and the rest of the
world thanks you.

STEVE CARSON: Thank you. Professor Miyagawa? SHIGERU MIYAGAWA:
Thank you, Derek.

I just want to reiterate
what I said at the beginning, that the MIT OpenCourseWare
is an effort.

It's a project of the
entire MIT community. And it really speaks, I think,
highly of this community

that so many people
are participating now. And that number
keeps increasing.

And now we are going beyond MIT. And you are very much
part of the community with your interest
and with your support.

And I just want to thank
you for your generosity in supporting OpenCourseWare.

STEVE CARSON: Thank you. And thank you once more for
joining us for the webcast. I realize there may
be some questions

that we didn't get a chance
to answer during our live time here. But if you send us those
questions in email,

or we'll look
through the comments that we've received on the web. We'll make sure that
we get back to you

with answers to those questions. So once again, for
all of us, thank you for joining us on this webcast.
